div.p: APRIL-DAY, A BURLETTA, IN THREE ACTS.
WRITTEN BY THE AUTHOR of MIDAS.
AS IT IS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL IN THE HAY-MARKET.
THE MUSIC compoſed by Dr. ARNOLD
LONDON: Printed for G. KEARSLY, No. 46, FLEET-STREET.

div.head: Extract of a Letter from the AUTHOR, to his Friend in LONDON.
div.p:
THE Interlude of the Magic Girdle, which Mr. Barthelemon left in my hands for correction, furniſhed me with the firſt hint of this Drama. I ſend you the original, that you may ſee my great reſerve in borrowing from it; at the ſame time, humbly begging pardon of the gentleman, unknown, with whoſe haſty ſketch I have taken ſo many liberties. This
Plot is here totally changed, and his Perſonages thrown into a different caſt of character: I have availed myſelf but very ſparingly of his words; ſcarce at all of his poetry.
I hope he will have the goodneſs to forgive me for what I have retained and what I have rejected, aſſuring him that, he is welcome to uſe ſtill greater licence with any work of mine.

I adopt the laconic Dialogue of Italian Burletta, in order to compriſe my Fable within the narrow limits of late preſcribed by the taſte of your audiences. This is ſhort enough to
admit their being indulged with ſome popular Petite Piece after it.

list.item: Don Buffalo, a fooliſh, ſwaggering, cowardly knave, ſuppoſed Guardian to Cephiſa. Mr. BANNISTER.
Count Folatre, A young Gentleman of worth, Cephiſa's lover. Mr. DU-BELLAMY
Davo, Folatre's ſervant, Intriguing and Truſty. Mr. EDWIN.
Cephiſa, A young heireſs in love with Folatre. Miſs TWIST.
Matilda, Cephiſa's maiden aunt, indulgent and chearful. Mrs. HITCHCOCK.

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: SCENE, a Chamber—MATILDA and CEPHISA, at the Tea Table.

l.hi: And on the fragrant lymph regale!
Hail Tea! thy grateful ſoothing ſteam
As ſugar ſweet, and ſoft as cream.
Perch'd on the margin of each cup
Hymen the nuptial torch lights up.
Drink Tea, ye brave and fair!
Drink Tea, ye brave and fair!

div.stage: They riſe and come forward laughing.

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.l: But apropos, child!—This ſame Hymen's torch—

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.l: Yes, think—come, tell not me;—you girls, do think,
And oft'times think, the hours of celibacy

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.l: Unleſs you think on't young, when old, you'll think,
And not be thought upon—why, here ſtand I now.

l.hi: I, in my giddy days—yes, I
Yet, was ſo nice, forſooth—ſo ſhy—
I ſcorn'd to fix on any.
But now from my tantrums emerging,
And am, to my grief a ſtale virgin.

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.p: Why, the caſe is piteous; (ſighing) But you, my dear! are, by your father's will, Secur'd againſt it.

sp.speaker: Ceph.
sp.l: That—"if within the year no match be offer'd,
"Shou'd grant conſent, I muſt, perforce, conſent

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.l: Further—"if you refuſe, then your whole fortune

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.l: Chooſe quickly, then—you've but this night to chooſe in.

sp.speaker: Ceph.
sp.l: That is, I wiſh—but no—and yet—a maiden—

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.p: Well judg'd! tho' both, perhaps, you yet might ſhun.

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.l: I'll try her— (to her) pray Cephiſa!
Laſt Sunday, in the circus, from our window—

l.hi: And how gracefully flouriſh'd his laſh!
All the reſt ſeem'd but traſh;
To the youth in the ſaſh.

sp.speaker: Ceph.
sp.l: A pair of dappled greys! I think, I did.

sp.speaker: Ceph.
sp.l: If this Folatre, with the dappled greys,

sp.speaker: Ceph.
sp.p: Why—no—yes—can't you gueſs?—in ſhort, dear aunt—

l.hi: That, how to get out o' this pucker,

lg.l: Unleſs you afford me your ſuccour.—

l.hi: As the light of my eyes.

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.l: A clue, indeed.—Their flame, I find is mutual!
Equal their truſt in me—I'll not forſake them—
Our don's a dolt, a vain chick-hearted bully:
His pride, with ſlatt'ry firſt, I'll ſooth: that failing,
His fear I will alarm. Next, on his folly,
By ſtratagem, I'll practiſe—huſh! I hear him—

div.stage: (Buffalo is heard bluſtering behind the ſcene.)

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: Hoa! Dunberblixen, charge my blunderbuſs—my rapier, Scolopendroz!
sp.stage: Enter a ſcald Ragamuffin, who kneels, and preſents him a ſword, then ſneaks off, trembling; he draws it arrogantly.
sp.l: Now, by thy blade, thy fate-diſpenſing blade!
What Caitiff grins this day, ſhall grin in—death.

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.stage: (laughing then advances with a low curtſy)
sp.l: With all humility I crave an audience.

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.l: Signior, to you, as guardian of Cephiſa,
Is now arriv'd at marriageable years— (curtſy)

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.l: Then, Signior, is it your good pleaſure
To doom her to the veil?

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.l: She liſtens to the vows of—Count Folatre?

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: My will—is reaſon—and my will it is,

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Yea, to the firſt, my hand.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: To ſet conteſting princeſſes at variance.

l.hi: Lives there—whoſe valour, blood, and talents,
To Buffalo muſt vail the bonnet,
To whom, for lineage high, Naſſau

lg.l: Muſt ſtrike the flag, and yield the pas.

div.stage: (He ſwaggers, ſhe eyes him with the utmoſt diſdain, then breaks out.)

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.l: Valour!—thou whipping poſt! valour! —where ſlept it,
When on the grand parade, this ſame Folatre
Can'd you? and tweak'd your noſe?

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: That Buffalo delib'rates, ere he acts.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: So, while I mus'd, his raſhneſs,
How with due dignity—beſt to chaſtiſe,

l.hi: That he can claim no ſhare in't.
He quakes, if I but frown.

p.hi: You frown on him! you daren't.

l.hi: He's a pet of your niece's;
That tongue yo' 'ad beſt rein in—

p.hi: By Styx, when I meet him, I'll beat him.
Yet, let me intreat you! not eat him.

l.hi: You may find him plaguy tough.
I ſhall find him, that's enough.

div.head: ACT II. The Street before BUFFALO's houſe.
div.stage: Enter COUNT FOLATRE, his ſervant DAVO following. They walk along, looking up to the window.

sp.speaker: Davo.
sp.p: Her aunt, my Lord, comes forth.

div.stage: Enter MATILDA, diſſatisfied. FOLATRE runs to meet her.

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.p: Count! your propoſals I tender'd to the Don.

sp.speaker: Fola.
sp.p:
Himſelf! (in dejection) I'm loſt—ay, this I fear'd. She—
She's a treaſure Not to be yeilded.

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.p: Do, Count? rouſe! uſe your wits! Uſe ſtratagem, diſguiſe! Our oaf's a ſubject For any, any practice.

l.hi: Make a chaos in my breaſt.
O Jove! vers'd in am'rous wile,

div.stage: FOLATRE plung'd in meditation, DAVO ſteps forward bowing.

sp.speaker: Davo.
sp.p: Pardon my lord—I ſee you're pos'd— permit me
Madam—I'm told, This Don has faith in the Black Art.

sp.speaker: Davo.
sp.l: On that I build—I play the Aſtrologer:
You puff me off t'him;—he comes to conſult me.
If my reſonſes make him not as eager

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.p: 'Twill make the fool run mad—I'll call Cephiſa.

sp.speaker: Fola.
sp.p: Diſpatch good Davo! run man! hire a chamber, Provide your properties.—

l.hi: Dancer of puppets have I been,
If ſome or other of theſe ſhapes,
I've an imp in my ſleeve
Juſt ready to pop out and ſeize him.

sp.speaker: Ceph.
sp.p: My aunt informs me—you've a plot in hand—

sp.speaker: Fola.
sp.l: We have, my angel!—One, on whoſe event

sp.speaker: Ceph.
sp.stage: (with tenderneſs, half aſide, with a ſigh)

div.stage: AIR, DUETT, which changes to a TRIO, and afterwards a QUARTETTO.

l.hi: Say, maid ador'd! Say! Heavenly Fair!
Honour can grant, and love demand.

p.hi: They claim—in me they claim—your hand.

l.hi: The little all I can, I give.

p.hi: And I, as heav'ns beſt boon, receive.

l.hi: And wiſe are they, who fly.
The man who pull'd your noſe.
The man who pull'd your noſe.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: This arm, who, (drawing and moving towards him) &c.

l.hi: Stripling, you owe to the police
That bloodleſs, I reſheath my ſword;
For I'm bound over to the peace.

p.hi: A good come off, upon my word!

l.hi: Ay, you can now be brave.

div.stage: Exit Buffalo, and afterwards the others.
SCENE, A Chamber, Buffalo ſolus, muſing,

sp.speaker: Buſſ
sp.l: (feigns) Sa, ſa! There I could drill him.— Puts up.
Get him laid under an arreſt:

l.hi: How great a bleſſing to my foes,
That, when my wrath could tear'em,
For my ward, fame, and bones.

div.stage: Enter Matilda, as out of breath.

l.hi: To be out o' th' way,
Where a plague could you ſtay?
I but to the Conj'ror ſtept,
Newly ſlipt down from the regious
He told me the ſecrets of all my paſt life:
He told me how oft' I might have been a wife;
Told how this Knight wheedled, and how that Lord ſwore,
He told me whut follow'd, told what went before;
At laſt, in a whiſper, he told ſomething more,

div.stage:
RECITATIVE.
Buff. (aſide, ruminating)
This is paſt coz'nage, no juggling here. (To her, looking wiſe)
Aſtrology was ever held a ſcience.
Inſcrutable, infallible, incredible.
Such hold it I, and therefore hold firm faith in't.
Matil. (cajoling him)
Moſt juſty reaſon'd, Signior!
Buff. (flattered)
Yes, I propoſe
To commune with this Sage, from him to learn
All, what my love, or fortunes may concern.— (Going, ſtops)
AIR.
Yet, what need I
Conſult the sky,
On ſtars above dependant?
Are not Cephiſa's eyes
My ſtars, my deſtinies,
And lords of my aſcendant?
Exit.
div.p: As Buffalo goes out, enter (at another Door) Cephiſa.

sp.speaker: Ceph.
sp.l: Lord, Aunt! I thought your conf'rence with the Don
Would never end. Where went he?

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.l: To perfect a ſmall bond to me.

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.l: Yes, poor ten thouſand crowns, condition'd ſolely
That I win you, to place your love on him,
And to diſcard the Count; that's all. Now, Cephiſa!

sp.speaker: Ceph.
sp.l: And you—you to betray me?—'tis too much.

l.hi: Like her ſlave, or her beaſt;

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.l: Nay more, we have a plot to terrify him.
Davo will boaſt the powers of magic art,
And thus diſguis'd ſo work upon his fears,
That he ſhall trembie at the thoughts of marriage,
And beg Folatre to accept your hand.

sp.speaker: Ceph.
sp.l: I'll follow, to be ready at the landing.
(with emotion) Why palpitates my heart? do I not ſee
That this clod's pride, and fear, and ſuperſtition,
All op'rate to our aid? (ſighs) wou'd 'twere well over!

l.hi: Of ſhelves, ſhoa • s, winds, and ſeas.
My cargo's love; wedlock, my port;

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: MATIL.
sp.p: THESE are the conj'ror's chambers. Here I leave you.

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.p: He ſees but one at once—good ſtars t'ye!

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Unſeen, to know and name me—Strange indeed!

div.stage: The ſtage is darken'd, and the ſcene flying open, Davo is ſeen ſitting gravely at the table in a magician's habit, awfully waving his wand, while Buffalo ſtands ſilent in terror and amaze.

sp.speaker: Davo.
sp.l: In me, Don Buffalo! in me thou ſeeſt
The type, the proto-type, the arche-type
O'th' myſtic Cabala—Me, the nine planets,
Their Major Domo—Me, th' ecliptic comets,
Their aid-de-camp—Me, the bear's arctic, catarctic,
Saturnus, Urnus, Ops, Hydrops, Libra, Zebra,
(Wi' the reſt of the menagerie celeſtial)

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.stage: (in a tremulous voice, and bowing low)—

sp.speaker: Davo.
sp.l: Occult, incult, difficult, excult, I fathom;

sp.speaker: Davo.
sp.l: I can erect, deject, detect, direct,

lg.head: RECITATIVE.
lg.stage: (bowing with reverend dread, and laying his purſe at Davo's feet)
lg.l: Sage Daemogorgon, central point of ſcience!

sp.speaker: Davo.
sp.l: Thy liberality hath won our favour.

sp.speaker: Davo.
sp.l: There is—I know't—a maid, thy ward, Cephiſa,

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Nay then, the Devil's his prompter.

sp.speaker: Davo.
sp.p: The ſtars frown on that union—wed her not.

p.hi: She hath a ſpell upon her.

l.hi: I ſay, a ſpell upon her.
I ſay, a ſpell upon her.
Of Stars! of Arts! of Science▪
Once there, I dread no harms,

sp.speaker: Davo.
sp.l: Rebel! ſince my 'monitions thou regard'ſt not,
Daemons themſelves ſhall ſpeak to thee. Stand clear!

div.stage: Waves his wand, and draws a circle on the floor.— Buffalo ſpring aſide, trembling

sp.speaker: Davo.
sp.l: Up from the murky den of night,

div.stage: Thunder—a flaſh, Folatre riſes, diſguiſed as a frightful Daemon.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Angels and Miniſters of Grace defend us!

sp.speaker: Fola.
sp.l: But tremble not, and be your fears diſmiſt.

l.hi: Nor ſcar'd by my grim feature!
Know, Don, I come, your life to ſave,
To drag you from the yawning grave,
Me, Buffalo, be ſure to prove,
In all the offices of love,
My ſervices can ſcarce be told,
The fearful lover I make bold,
And warm the heart that freezes.
Ere he can ſnatch one kiſs,
He will be ſtruck—Sc • r • utic,

sp.speaker: Davo.
sp.p: Now infidel! ſt • ll doubt'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: Pardon! great ſage! I am convinc'd—not worlds

sp.speaker: Davo
sp.l: Not firſt—no—not firſt. (touching him with the wand)
Riſe, Don! now liſt the words of inſpiration.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.stage: (raiſing himſelf on his knees, with up-lighted hands)

sp.speaker: Davo.
sp.l: Thus they—"Thou haſt one mortal "foe—a count;

sp.speaker: Davo.
sp.l: "So is ſhe freed, and ſo the ſpell diſſolves."

l.hi: His bliſs ſhall be his bane;
A couch for death and pain.
But the ſecond, Oh Heav'n! the ſecond,
The happieſt of men ſhall be reckon'd;
The ſecond bleſt ſpouſe ſhe's decreed to,
Shall find her a virgin and widow.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: Thanks, thanks, kind Doemogorgon!—Yes, I do;

div.stage: Davo waves his wand, a roll of parchment falls from above: he takes it upand unrolls it.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: There ſage! 'tis ſign'd. (delivers it) Folatre be the firſt,
And Buffalo, the happy ſecond ſpouſe!

l.hi: The fates his promis'd joys ſhall blight;
Furies the nuptial torch ſhall light;
And on the bed, where Cupids play,
Black imps a winding ſheet ſhall lay,
And give the devil his due.
And then, the pride of ſtory,
The loves and graces ſhall attend,
Each flying hour on purple wing,
New joy, new revelry, ſhall bring,

div.stage: After the Air, Matilda, Cephiſa, and Folatre, in his own habit, come from behind the ſkreen.

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.l: Yes, Don, we'll witneſs to your deed and bliſs;
When the Count dies, you're ſure of Cephiſa.

sp.speaker: Fola
sp.p: But an April maſque—I play'd the Daemon!

sp.speaker: Davo.
sp.p: The conj'ror I, ſage Davo, at your ſervice.

div.stage: Buffalo hangs down his head; then, in deſperation, runs with his drawn ſword at Davo.

sp.speaker: Matil.
sp.l: This day is Folly's feſtival—You, Signior,
Tho' not the only one, perhaps the chief
Of our examples—from our plot amend!

l.hi: Now you're pinn'd to the ſtake,

p.hi: Nay, leave me to deal with our ſir there.

l.hi: My ſweet ſecond ſpouſe would you murther?
Ye have humbled me— what would ye further?
Ye have humbled me—what would ye further.
